name: Perseids
description: The Perseids are one of the best meteor showers to observe, producing up to 100 meteors per hour at peak. They are famous for producing bright fireballs.
funFacts: Known since at least 36 AD, making it one of the oldest recorded showers.
The meteors are debris from Comet Swift-Tuttle.
Perseids can appear anywhere in the sky, but trace back to Perseus.
Best viewed in the Northern Hemisphere during warm summer nights.

name: Geminids
description: The Geminids are considered the most reliable annual meteor shower, producing up to 150 multicolored meteors per hour. Unusually, they originate from an asteroid rather than a comet.
funFacts: The only major meteor shower caused by an asteroid.
Produces meteors in multiple colors including white, yellow, green, and red.
Geminid meteors are denser than other shower meteors.
The shower is getting stronger over time.

name: Leonids
description: The Leonids are famous for producing meteor storms roughly every 33 years when Earth passes through dense debris trails. The 1833 storm produced hundreds of thousands of meteors per hour.
funFacts: The 1833 Leonid storm sparked modern meteor astronomy.
Leonids are the fastest meteors at 71 km/s.
Major storms occur roughly every 33 years.
The 1966 storm produced 40 meteors per second.

name: Quadrantids
description: The Quadrantids have a very short peak of only a few hours but can produce up to 120 meteors per hour. They are named after a now-defunct constellation.
funFacts: Named after the obsolete constellation Quadrans Muralis.
The peak lasts only about 6 hours.
May originate from a 'dead comet' that lost its ice.
Often missed due to poor January weather in the Northern Hemisphere.

name: Orionids
description: The Orionids are debris from the famous Halley's Comet. They produce fast meteors that often leave persistent trains.
funFacts: Orionids are debris from Halley's Comet.
Earth encounters this debris twice yearly (Orionids and Eta Aquariids).
The meteors are very fast at 66 km/s.
Often produce persistent glowing trains in the sky.

name: Lyrids
description: The Lyrids are one of the oldest known meteor showers, with records going back 2,700 years to ancient China. They occasionally produce outbursts of up to 100 meteors per hour.
funFacts: First recorded in 687 BC in China.
Lyrids occasionally produce outbursts of 100+ meteors per hour.
Comet Thatcher won't return until 2283.
The radiant is near the bright star Vega.

name: Eta Aquariids
description: The Eta Aquariids are the second meteor shower associated with Halley's Comet. They are best viewed from the Southern Hemisphere where they can produce 50+ meteors per hour.
funFacts: Sister shower to the Orionids, both from Halley's Comet.
Better viewed from the Southern Hemisphere.
Meteors can be seen up to half the night.
Fast meteors at 66 km/s, similar to Orionids.

name: Taurids
description: The Taurids are a long-lasting shower known for producing exceptionally bright fireballs. They occur in two branches: Northern and Southern Taurids.
funFacts: Famous for producing spectacular fireballs.
The slowest major meteor shower at 27 km/s.
Active for over 3 months, the longest of any shower.
Some scientists link Taurids to the Tunguska event.
